channel.title: Home on Ashish's Site
channel.description: Recent content in Home on Ashish's Site

item.title: July 23
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: Hello again! This is going to be a short one. Ever had the moment when you are working in multiple branches and you have to switch between them? I have. Recently, I’ve been using two shortcut quite a lot. Git provides us a handy shortcut for this situation. git checkout - This command checkouts to the previous working branch. This is quite helpful when you’re juggling between 2 branches.

item.title: July 12
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: Hey readers, thanks for coming back here. While working on one of the bugfixes for a new project, I came across an interesting piece of code written by one of my colleague. The basic idea is of the problem is to get a value from dict with lots of nested objects, about 5-6 levels deep. There are quite a few variants of dict that we get, but for a variation, path of keys is same.

item.title: Cheatsheets
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: ============= Website Update alert!!! =============== Hello there, hope you’re having a wonderful day. New section Cheatsheets is added in the website. As of today, it contains the sections: Gcloud, Docker, and Kubernetes This sheets will contains things that I use regularly, but can’t bother to remember them. That’s it folk, see ya!

item.title: Basics
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: List all authenticated credentials (principals) gcloud auth list Make another account active gcloud config set account `ACCOUNT` Activate Service account (if new and no principals) gcloud auth activate-service-account --key-file=/path/to/key.json

item.title: Basics
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: See all running pods docker ps See all ran pods docker ps -a Remove <none> (dangling) images docker rmi $(docker images -f "dangling=true" -q) Remove all containers docker rm $(docker ps -aq) Remove images conatining keyword docker rmi -f $(docker images | grep 'keyword' | awk '{print $1}')

item.title: Basics
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: Alias kubectl to kc for easy typing alias kc="kubectl" List all the available namespaces kc get namespace Get all pods running in namespace kc get pods -n namespace Get all pods running in namespace kc logs <pod> -n namespace Get all resource running in namespace kc logs resource/<resource_name> -n namespace Eg: kc logs services/xyz -n namespace Alias: List all the pods and see the logs of selected (requires fzf) alias kcl='kubectl get pods -n <namespace> | fzf | awk '\''{print $1}'\'' | xargs kubectl logs -n <namespace>' Alias: List all contexts and switch between them (requires fzf) alias kx='kubectl config get-contexts | awk '\''{print $2}'\'' | fzf | xargs kubectl config use-context'

item.title: Debugging
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: View resource usage (top) of different pods kc top pods -n namespace Get a shell to the running container kc exec --stdin --tty <pod-name> -n namespace -- /bin/bash Note: The double dash (--) separates the arguments you want to pass to the command from the kubectl arguments. List all environment variables in the running container kc exec <pod-name> env -n namespace Opening a shell when a Pod has more than one container kc exec -i -t <pod-name> -n namespace --container main-app -- /bin/bash Reference: https://kubernetes.

item.title: Making My Life Easier with Bash/Zsh Function
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: Intro Hello everyone, it’s been such a long time since my last blog. Life’s been busy and have not been able to update the blog as I thought I would. Anyway, new post incoming. Unlike every other people on the planet, I use pyenv virtualenv to create virtualenv. Reasons: For me is to easily switch between python version depending on the repo, as my workplace maintains repos with 2 python versions.

item.title: How I come up with my instagram captions using Python and Scrapy
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: Note: This is an article I wrote a while back. Enjoy Greetings readers! I know that the title is kind of misleading so let me begin with a context. There are days when you click a perfect picture and you want to upload it in instagram, and everyone knows the unwritten rule of any social media â€” you need to have a caption to match the picture. Now you could go to google or any search engine and search for something that matches the picture but what if you know how to code.

item.title: About
item.author: iamashishsubedi@gmail.com (Ashish Subedi)
item.description: Welcome! Iâ€™m Ashish, a software engineer with around 4 years of experience specializing in backend and system design. My expertise extends to ML, AI, and LLMs, encompassing everything from traditional machine learning algorithms to complex deep neural networks. If youâ€™ve stumbled here by chance or curiosity, welcome! This is my personal corner of the internet where I share a mix of thoughts and ideasâ€”some practical, others just for fun. Itâ€™s a place for me to reflect on my experiences and interests, and I hope you find something that piques your interest as you browse around!
